100.headline: 100 Continue
100.summary: The initial part of a request has been received and has not yet been rejected by the server. The server intends to send a final response after the request has been fully received and acted upon.

101.headline: 101 Switching Protocols
101.summary: The server understands and is willing to comply with the client's request, via the Upgrade header field1, for a change in the application protocol being used on this connection.

102.headline: 102 Processing
102.summary: An interim response used to inform the client that the server has accepted the complete request, but has not yet completed it.

200.headline: 200 OK
200.summary: The request has succeeded.  a 200 response always has a payload, though an origin server MAY generate a payload body of zero length. If no payload is desired, an origin server ought to send 204 No Content instead.

201.headline: 201 Created
201.summary: The request has been fulfilled and has resulted in one or more new resources being created.

202.headline: 202 Accepted
202.summary:
The request has been accepted for processing, but the processing has not been
completed. The request might or might not eventually be acted upon, as it might
be disallowed when processing actually takes place.

203.headline: 203 Non-authoritative Information
203.summary: The request was successful but the enclosed payload has been modified from that of the origin server's 200 OK response by a transforming proxy1.

204.headline: 204 No Content
204.summary: The server has successfully fulfilled the request and that there is no additional content to send in the response payload body.

205.headline: 205 Reset Content
205.summary: The server has fulfilled the request and desires that the user agent reset the "document view", which caused the request to be sent, to its original state as received from the origin server.

206.headline: 206 Partial Content
206.summary: The server is successfully fulfilling a range request for the target resource by transferring one or more parts of the selected representation that correspond to the satisfiable ranges found in the request's Range header field1.

207.headline: 207 Multi-Status
207.summary: A Multi-Status response conveys information about multiple resources in situations where multiple status codes might be appropriate.

208.headline: 208 Already Reported
208.summary: Used inside a DAV: propstat response element to avoid enumerating the internal members of multiple bindings to the same collection repeatedly.

226.headline: 226 IM Used
226.summary: The server has fulfilled a GET request for the resource, and the response is a representation of the result of one or more instance-manipulations applied to the current instance.

300.headline: 300 Multiple Choices
300.summary: The target resource has more than one representation, each with its own more specific identifier, and information about the alternatives is being provided so that the user (or user agent) can select a preferred representation by redirecting its request to one or more of those identifiers.

301.headline: 301 Moved Permanently
301.summary: The target resource has been assigned a new permanent URI and any future references to this resource ought to use one of the enclosed URIs.

302.headline: 302 Found
302.summary: The target resource resides temporarily under a different URI. Since the redirection might be altered on occasion, the client ought to continue to use the effective request URI for future requests.

303.headline: 303 See Other
303.summary: The server is redirecting the user agent to a different resource, as indicated by a URI in the Location header field, which is intended to provide an indirect response to the original request.

304.headline: 304 Not Modified
304.summary: A conditional GET or HEAD request has been received and would have resulted in a 200 OK response if it were not for the fact that the condition evaluated to false.

305.headline: 305 Use Proxy
305.summary: Defined in a previous version of this specification and is now deprecated, due to security concerns regarding in-band configuration of a proxy.

307.headline: 307 Temporary Redirect
307.summary: The target resource resides temporarily under a different URI and the user agent MUST NOT change the request method if it performs an automatic redirection to that URI.

308.headline: 308 Permanent Redirect
308.summary: The target resource has been assigned a new permanent URI and any future references to this resource ought to use one of the enclosed URIs.

400.headline: 400 Bad Request
400.summary: The server cannot or will not process the request due to something that is perceived to be a client error (e.g., malformed request syntax, invalid request message framing, or deceptive request routing).

401.headline: 401 Unauthorized
401.summary: The request has not been applied because it lacks valid authentication credentials for the target resource.

403.headline: 403 Forbidden
403.summary: The server understood the request but refuses to authorize it.

404.headline: 404 Not Found
404.summary: The origin server did not find a current representation for the target resource or is not willing to disclose that one exists.

405.headline: 405 Method Not Allowed
405.summary: The method received in the request-line is known by the origin server but not supported by the target resource.

406.headline: 406 Not Acceptable
406.summary: The target resource does not have a current representation that would be acceptable to the user agent, according to the proactive negotiation header fields received in the request1, and the server is unwilling to supply a default representation.

407.headline: 407 Proxy Authentication Required
407.summary: Similar to 401 Unauthorized, but it indicates that the client needs to authenticate itself in order to use a proxy.

408.headline: 408 Request Timeout
408.summary: The server did not receive a complete request message within the time that it was prepared to wait.

409.headline: 409 Conflict
409.summary: The request could not be completed due to a conflict with the current state of the target resource. This code is used in situations where the user might be able to resolve the conflict and resubmit the request.

410.headline: 410 Gone
410.summary: The target resource is no longer available at the origin server and that this condition is likely to be permanent.

411.headline: 411 Length Required
411.summary: The server refuses to accept the request without a defined Content-Length1.

412.headline: 412 Precondition Failed
412.summary: One or more conditions given in the request header fields evaluated to false when tested on the server.

413.headline: 413 Payload Too Large
413.summary: The server is refusing to process a request because the request payload is larger than the server is willing or able to process.

414.headline: 414 Request-URI Too Long
414.summary: The server is refusing to service the request because the request-target1 is longer than the server is willing to interpret.

415.headline: 415 Unsupported Media Type
415.summary: The origin server is refusing to service the request because the payload is in a format not supported by this method on the target resource.

416.headline: 416 Requested Range Not Satisfiable
416.summary: None of the ranges in the request's Range header field1 overlap the current extent of the selected resource or that the set of ranges requested has been rejected due to invalid ranges or an excessive request of small or overlapping ranges.

417.headline: 417 Expectation Failed
417.summary: The expectation given in the request's Expect header field1 could not be met by at least one of the inbound servers.

418.headline: 418 I'm a teapot
418.summary: Any attempt to brew coffee with a teapot should result in the error code "418 I'm a teapot". The resulting entity body MAY be short and stout.

421.headline: 421 Misdirected Request
421.summary: The request was directed at a server that is not able to produce a response. This can be sent by a server that is not configured to produce responses for the combination of scheme and authority that are included in the request URI.

422.headline: 422 Unprocessable Entity
422.summary: The server understands the content type of the request entity (hence a 415 Unsupported Media Type status code is inappropriate), and the syntax of the request entity is correct (thus a 400 Bad Request status code is inappropriate) but was unable to process the contained instructions.

423.headline: 423 Locked
423.summary: The source or destination resource of a method is locked.

424.headline: 424 Failed Dependency
424.summary: The method could not be performed on the resource because the requested action depended on another action and that action failed.

426.headline: 426 Upgrade Required
426.summary: The server refuses to perform the request using the current protocol but might be willing to do so after the client upgrades to a different protocol.

428.headline: 428 Precondition Required
428.summary: The origin server requires the request to be conditional.

429.headline: 429 Too Many Requests
429.summary: The user has sent too many requests in a given amount of time ("rate limiting").

431.headline: 431 Request Header Fields Too Large
431.summary: The server is unwilling to process the request because its header fields are too large. The request MAY be resubmitted after reducing the size of the request header fields.

444.headline: 444 Connection Closed Without Response
444.summary: A non-standard status code used to instruct nginx to close the connection without sending a response to the client, most commonly used to deny malicious or malformed requests.

451.headline: 451 Unavailable For Legal Reasons
451.summary: The server is denying access to the resource as a consequence of a legal demand.

499.headline: 499 Client Closed Request
499.summary: A non-standard status code introduced by nginx for the case when a client closes the connection while nginx is processing the request.

500.headline: 500 Internal Server Error
500.summary: The server encountered an unexpected condition that prevented it from fulfilling the request.

501.headline: 501 Not Implemented
501.summary: The server does not support the functionality required to fulfill the request.

502.headline: 502 Bad Gateway
502.summary: The server, while acting as a gateway or proxy, received an invalid response from an inbound server it accessed while attempting to fulfill the request.

503.headline: 503 Service Unavailable
503.summary: The server is currently unable to handle the request due to a temporary overload or scheduled maintenance, which will likely be alleviated after some delay.

504.headline: 504 Gateway Timeout
504.summary: The server, while acting as a gateway or proxy, did not receive a timely response from an upstream server it needed to access in order to complete the request.

505.headline: 505 HTTP Version Not Supported
505.summary: The server does not support, or refuses to support, the major version of HTTP that was used in the request message.

506.headline: 506 Variant Also Negotiates
506.summary: The server has an internal configuration error: the chosen variant resource is configured to engage in transparent content negotiation itself, and is therefore not a proper end point in the negotiation process.

507.headline: 507 Insufficient Storage
507.summary: The method could not be performed on the resource because the server is unable to store the representation needed to successfully complete the request.

508.headline: 508 Loop Detected
508.summary: The server terminated an operation because it encountered an infinite loop while processing a request with "Depth: infinity". This status indicates that the entire operation failed.

510.headline: 510 Not Extended
510.summary: The policy for accessing the resource has not been met in the request. The server should send back all the information necessary for the client to issue an extended request.

511.headline: 511 Network Authentication Required
511.summary: The client needs to authenticate to gain network access.

599.headline: 599 Network Connect Timeout Error
599.summary: This status code is not specified in any RFCs, but is used by some HTTP proxies to signal a network connect timeout behind the proxy to a client in front of the proxy.
